abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is satisfactory, and
            project sustainability is likely. World Bank and Borrower
            performances are satisfactory. Lessons learned regarding
            project preparation include: A bottom-up approach to project
            planning, design and implementation facilitates stakeholders
            commitment and ensures successful implementation. Reforms in
            curriculum, teaching-learning methods and student assessment
            need to be firmly grounded in labor market demands.
            Institutional development and its functional relevance to
            the community and the economy are best ensured through links
            with local enterprises and industries. Finalization of a
            staff training program before credit/loan effectiveness and
            early implementation will ensure that the trained staff will
            have adequate time to bring benefits to the project. Lessons
            related to project performance include: In support of
            decentralization, implementation responsibilities should be
            clearly delineated and strategically distributed to key
            agencies at national, provincial, local and institutional
            levels to ensure accountability and smooth coordination of
            project activities. Successful project implementation with
            multi-provinces/entities depends upon strong local capacity
            built with targeted assistance and dedicated agencies
            adequately staffed by trained personnel with the relevant
            skills and experience. In support of school-based
            management, establishment of School Boards (Governing
            Council) and Industrial Liaison Committees is an effective
            mechanism in embracing community participation and
            partnership with industries. Decentralized and
            provincial-based procurement under the guidance of
            experienced national implementing agency accelerates the
            procurement process, ensures end-user satisfaction, and
            builds up provincial procurement capacity. Early procurement
            training with close attention to contract management issues
            will facilitate the establishment of a mechanism for
            post-delivery follow-up service to end-users. Effective
            communication between service providers and end-users is
            essential for assessing user needs and providing quality
            service for ICB procurement. Special accounts administered
            by sector implementing agencies is likely to be more
            efficient in facilitating timely disbursement and reducing delays.
